title: 114_s1550
content: The "Program Management Improvement Accountability Act" establishes governmentwide standards for program and project management in executive agencies. The Deputy Director for Management is responsible for overseeing the implementation of these standards, chairing the Program Management Policy Council, and engaging with the private sector to identify best practices. The Act establishes standards for program and project management in executive agencies, including engaging with the private sector, conducting portfolio reviews, and creating a 5-year strategic plan. The Department of Defense is exempt if similar provisions exist in chapter 87 of title 10. The Act exempts the Department of Defense from certain provisions if they are already covered in chapter 87 of title 10 or related policies. The Deputy Director for Management of the Office of Management and Budget must issue standards, policies, and guidelines within one year of the Act's enactment. Regulations must be issued within 90 days after the standards are released. The Deputy Director for Management of the Office of Management and Budget, in consultation with the Program Management Policy Council, will issue regulations to implement the requirements of section 503(c) of title 31, United States Code. Chapter 11 of title 31, United States Code, is amended to include the designation of Program Management Improvement Officers in agencies to implement program management policies. The Program Management Improvement Officer designated by an agency must implement program management policies and develop a strategy to enhance the role of program managers, including providing enhanced training opportunities. The Program Management Improvement Officer must provide training in relevant competencies for program and project managers in the private sector, focusing on cost containment for large projects and programs. The Program Management Improvement Officer aims to enhance program management by mentoring current and future managers, improving career paths, recruiting qualified individuals, sharing best practices, and providing tools for data analysis. This does not apply to the Department of Defense if similar provisions exist in chapter 87 of title 10. The Program Management Improvement Officer, under the Under Secretary of Defense for Acquisition, Technology, and Logistics, is established to enhance program management by mentoring managers, improving career paths, and providing tools for data analysis. The Program Management Policy Council, established in the Office of Management and Budget, serves as the principal interagency forum for improving agency practices related to program and project management. The Program Management Policy Council, established in the Office of Management and Budget, reviews high-risk programs, discusses workforce development, advises on program management standards, and reviews information on the OMB website. The Program Management Policy Council in the Office of Management and Budget includes key positions such as the Deputy Director for Management, Administrator of the Office of Electronic Government, Administrator of Federal Procurement Policy, Controller of the Office of Federal Financial Management, and Director of the Office of Performance and Personnel Management. The Program Management Improvement Officer from each agency and designated federal employees or Armed Forces members are part of the Council. The Chairperson, the Deputy Director for Management of the Office of Management and Budget, presides over meetings, sets the agenda, and directs the Council's work. Meetings are held at least twice per fiscal year, with support from agency heads with a Project. The Council meets at least twice per fiscal year, with support from agency heads. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget must submit a report to Congress within one year of the Act's enactment. Regulations for Program and Project Management Personnel Standards must be issued within 180 days. In this subsection, the term "agency" refers to agencies described in section 901(b) of title 31, United States Code, excluding the Department of Defense. The Director of the Office of Personnel Management, in consultation with the Director of the Office of Management and Budget, must issue regulations within 180 days after the issuance of standards, policies, and guidelines under section 503(c) of title 31, United States Code. These regulations will identify key skills and competencies, establish or update job series for program and project management, and create a new career path for program and project managers within agencies. The Government Accountability Office will issue a report on the effectiveness of policies on improving Federal program and project management, including standards, guidelines, strategic plans, Program Management Improvement Officers, and the Program Management Policy Council.
